Levin and Stabenow back Sun Country's application for route
By David Shepardson Detroit News Washington Bureau
Washington - Four senators are urging the U.S. Transportation Department to approve direct flights from Michigan's capital to the nation's capital.
Sun Country Airlines has applied for an unused gate at Washington, D.C.'s, Ronald Reagan National Airport.
The airline would use the slot to fly between Washington and Lansing, with continuing service to Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport.

Democratic U.S. Sens. Carl Levin of Detroit and Debbie Stabenow of Lansing, as well as Minnesota Democratic U.S. Sens. Amy Klobuchar and Al Franken, wrote Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood seeking his approval of the request by the Minnesota-based low-cost airline.
Approval "would save travelers millions of dollars in lower fares" for travelers in Minnesota and Michigan, they said.
The senators said approving the service could boost economic development.

"The Lansing region caters to state and federal agencies, nonprofit organizations and many growing businesses that require transportation to D.C. as a part of their professions. It is inconvenient that Lansing, as the capital of Michigan, currently lacks a direct flight to Washington, D.C.," they wrote.

"Lansing is a convenient terminal for the 90 percent of Michigan residents who live within 90 minutes of the city. Michigan travelers would clearly benefit from the competition and reduction in airfare provided by Sun Country."
The Transportation Department declined to comment.
Other carriers, including Southwest Airlines and US Airways, also are vying for the two open slots at Reagan National Airport.
